reviewText:
Before people blow up the comments on this review, I played this game before it was on Steam which is why my playtime is practically nonexistent.

Details of gameplay are mentioned as applicable to each section.

PROS:
+ Simpler gameplay than MMDoC, MtG, or Hearthstone might appeal to those who find such games too complicated. There are currently no effects (poison, lifesteal, retaliation, etc.) At its core, BoE has damage (as well as bonus damage, which is added to damage only if it's dealt), defense, and healing. Defense is subtracted from damage for each player and the net total is applied. Healing then heals any missing health. That's all there is to it.
+ Novel and not P2W card system--gameplay works like this: The game generates a random deck of cards for you in each game, depending on skill levels and other factors. Initially, you will draw all your cards from here. At the end of a match, any cards you played get added to your Stash". Cards in your stash can then be added to a "Collector's Deck" (which is an alternate deck you can choose to draw from during a match) or can be converted to gold (used to buy other cards). Therefore it's sometimes recommended to avoid playing a beneficial card in order to save enough energy/mana to play a rare card just so you can keep it.
+ Some RPG-like elements. Levelling gives you stat points which you can apply to your hero in order to increase things like energy
hoursPlayed:
etc. This helps reduce some of the RNGsus-ness from the game as you'll have a noticeably easier time defeating certain opponents if you've applied your points in a constructive way.
+ Nice music
+ A developer/company rep is currently active in the forums. Currently there are only a few posts there so I don't know how long that'll last but it's always nice to see someone around and feel like you're being heard.

CONS:
- That simple gameplay feels redundant after a while and may not be appealing to more experienced TCG players.
- Less variety than other games. In terms of playable classes
voteText: MMDoc has six factions
votesHelpful: and Hearthstone has nine. This game has three
votesTotal: and they form sort of a rock-paper-scissors triangle. In terms of card variation
votesFunny: the lack of game mechanics more complicated than direct damage means practically every card either heals
column17: or adds defense.\n- There's very little room for strategy formation or planning. A turn consists of drawing cards (until you have five)
column21: and then discarding zero or one card. There are no permanents; most equipped cards last 4-6 turns before disappearing. Where BoE deviates from most other games is in the combat. You don't have creatures that exist on the battlefield so much as you have cards that deal damage for a turn (occasionally two or rarely three) and are then discarded. Therefore
column22: the only real planning takes place when deciding when to play a card that lingers for more than a turn. For example
column23: you might have a card that deals bonus damage and last two turns and another card that deals normal damage but only lasts one turn. If you don't have enough mana to play both
column24: you'd have to play the bonus damage first (it wouldn't do anything without normal damage to add to) and play the normal damage card the next turn
column25: at which point the bonus damage would take effect once before disappearing. That's really all there is for strategy though; the main goals in this game are keeping your health up (so your opponent can't one-hit you) and making sure you have enough cards that deal normal damage (since there's quite an abundance of cards that deal bonus damage and you never seem to have enough cards you can use them with).\n- You can only play as one class. If you'd like to try either of the other two
column26:
you need to pay real money. This is frustrating since it means you'll have to play on various guest accounts to really test out strategies and get a feel for which hero is for you.
- Some balance issues exist

Overall rating: 6.5/10
column27: it's worth giving it a shot if you're not typically a TCG player. For the rest of us though
column28: Battlegrounds of Eldhelm feels wanting of more complex gameplay."

reviewText:
before reading: It's free, it's balanced, it's 100 mb and it's not pay to win. Play the game.

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------

I always wanted a card game where you controll only 1 character and the cards are your actions and I was glad to find this on steam but I had never expected such a good game.

This is the most balanced card game I have ever played. It's is not as much luck based as it is strategy based.
When you level up you level up good and yet I found myself having a hard time fighting a level 2 in multiplayer while I was level 10.

A lot of depth in strategy , a ton of things to do like some good game modes to play and quests etc and a hell of a good game.

Note: I play all kinds of games. Also love card games like MTG etc

reviewText:
Easy to play casual CCGPlaying it on Steam as well as on my tablet. Simple game to get into, easy to pick up & put away, very beautiful hand-crafted art, not really pay2win.

Who is this game for?
If you want to try a CCG for the first-time, or if you're a CCG player looking for something simple.

What's good about it?
Very easy to play for a bit then put away, simple game to get started with, beautiful graphics, it's not really p2w.
It is a tablet-port, but it's really not that noticeable or disruptive.

How does the game work?
I would suggest giving the tutorial a shot. It's fairly short but gives you a good understanding of the game.

Each player has an amount of energy points, these are used to play cards. Each card has a energy cost and there are cards that can affect your or your enemy's energy.

Each round consists of 5 phases
Draw phase
Equip phase
Attack/Defense phase
Discard phase
BattlePlayers take turn playing out the phases, ie. first player goes through draw, equip, attack and discard phase, then the other player goes through draw, equip, defense and discard phase (while seeing the other players attack cards laid out). Then the battle commences.

Draw phase: In this phase you draw cards from either the random deck or from your collector deck. Either player can draw from the random deck. Your hand can have at most 5 cards, and you can draw at most 3 cards at a time.

Equip phase: During this phase you can use equipment cards from your deck. They give different bonuses to stats such as; +damage, +defense, -enemy energy, etc.

Battle phase works as follows; the damage, defense and healing of each players cards are summed up, then the reduce damage, reduce defense, etc. of each players cards are subtracted, and what's left is the damage caused to each player.

When a match is over, the cards that you've played from the random deck are added to your card stash and then you can choose to transfer them to your collector deck. This is one way to acquire cards.

Simple enough, right?

Character creation
When you start playing the game you get to create a character by choosing one of the three races; human, orc or elf.
Humans have two classes to choose from; knight and rogue.
Orcs only have one class; warrior.
Elves have two classes to choose from; archer and mage.
Your race/class choice affects your characters stats and there are some cards that can only be used by specific classes.
Then you choose between a few alternatives to configure the appearance of your portrait.

Eventually your character will level up, and your character stats increase.

Simplicity
This is a very simple CCG; but what does that mean?
It is a game that is very easy to learn and the matches do not take a lot of time to play out.
Cards are easy to understand; cards either affect damage, defense, health or energy. There are a few special card effects like bleed and poison.
The only real difference between cards are the energy points they cost to play and the amount they affect a stat.

Singleplayer
There is a singleplayer campaign that you can play through and after that there are daily quests and some sidequests too.
If you're bored just playing against AI, you can throw yourself into the

Multiplayer
There are a few different multiplayer modes to try out; Arena, Challenge, Slay the Beast
Arena Your opponent is chosen at random. You will use only a special random deck! You will have to complete 5 arena or challenge matches to get ranked, then you will start gaining score points.
Challenge You will have to invite your opponent from a lobby. You will have to complete 5 arena or challenge matches to get ranked, then you will start gaining score points.
Slay the Beast Players fight simultaneously against a very powerful boss-like enemy. The ones who survive and those who injure the beast the most will get a rich reward.

reviewText:
I rather enjoyed this game, though it does have major faults.

First is the lack of longevity. (personally it took me 2 days to beat the solo campaign and after beating it you're only left with multi-player)

Second would be the lack of players for multi-player. This is especially true for those next to your level bracket. It makes it hard to even find a match at all, and forget about finding a well balanced one.

Third would be the length of time between tournaments, I have yet to participate in one and I been waiting just over a month for news about when the next one will be, (they still haven't posted it yet)

Even though these may be only 3 faults listed, they are in fact hefty ones. Even though I did enjoy this game for the few days it took me to complete the campaign, the fact is, after the first 2 days the action quickly came to a Halt, where its been ever since.

reviewText:
This is a rather simple and casual CCG with pretty much no complexity. You don't really have to strain your brain on this one, game requires very minimal thinking due to the lack of card effects, but more so on that later.

Once you beat the tutorial you'll have to create a character (you have to pay real money if you want to have more then one character). You can pick between 3 different races (Orcs, Humans, Elves). Orcs have only one class which is Warrior, Humans have Knight and Rogue while Elves have Archer and Mage. Each class has different stats and different class-specific cards it can use.

The main problem in this game is the previously mentioned lack of complexity. Pretty much all cards will do one of the following: Deal damage to enemy, Increase your defense, Decrease enemy defense, Heal you, Increase your energy (mana),  Decrease enemy damage. The only difference between those cards is the energy cost and the numeric value of their effect and the fact that some of them will do multiple of those effects. Due to that there's very minimal amount of strategy and thinking involved with this game.

In the match, you'll have Random Deck and Collector Deck. You can draw cards from either of them during the Draw Phase. Once the match is over the cards that you used from Random Deck are added to your Stash and you can then transfer cards from Stash to your Collector Deck. You can only have 10 cards in your collector deck when your character is level one, but you gain more slots in collector deck as you level your character up.

When your character levels up you can increase his HP, Energy, Regeneration (heal per turn), Might (extra damage) or Resistance (extra defense). This is an interesting feature, but if you get matched against enemy who's level is higher then yours you'll be at disadvantage (I haven't played enough to know how good is their match making system).

Now would I recommend this game? I don't know really. I wish the game had more complexity to it but maybe it will have in the future. I'd say if you're a fan of CCG's or are interested in them and what you've read in this review didn't make you not want to ever try this game, then do give it a try. After all it's free and only about 100 MB to download so if nothing else it's worth giving a try. Just do keep in mind you're likely to find it boring if you're not into casual games.
voteText: 13 of 23 people (57%) found this review helpful

reviewText:
I wholeheartedly recommend this game to anyone who likes RPGs and CCGs. It merges the two amazingly well.

I love it that you can play a match wihout creating an account, so you are really free to decide if you like it or not, and then take the next step. The tutorial is helpful, the game can be understood easily. It is a bit overwhelming, but after you realize that you can level up faster by playing some multiplayer games (even if you lose, you get lots of XP), you can get the Energy Points required to make strategic, in-depth moves, even with the limited collection and play area you have.

I absolutely love the level up system, basically you decide how you want to play the game. Would you like more Health or more Energy? Do you want to expand your Hand or make your Buff area bigger? Do you want to get more gold and XP for each win? Or are you going for a huge Collector's Deck? You decide.
The card art is very nice, and the multiple combos you can pull with almost all cards is an excellent idea. You can turn any weak attack into some serious pain with the combos, which makes it so that no card is really worthless.

Collecting cards is really easy, you don't have to buy any packs. You just play the game, and as you draw cards, you always get to keep the ones you played. These cards go into your Stash, out of which you can pick multiple ones and put them in your Collector Deck, which will accompany you on future matches. It also makes you think more strategically in the beginning, as well: do you want to play your regular cards for a guaranteed effect, or do you want to spend more Energy on playing that Rare/Elite/Epic card you pulled, so you can add it to your collection?

All in all, it's a very good game with a somewhat dwindling population (sadly), but I was able to find human opponents whenever I really wanted to. Even if you can't/don't want to, there's a nice Campaign and Quest mode, where you can just play and collect cards.

reviewText: As a game about cards that add 1-4 turn bonuses to a handful of numbers goes, this one is remarkably complex. There are a lot of numbers that either become vastly less or more important when they can reduce an enemy's number to 0, so picking the number cards you need for the moment is a reasonably thoughtful affair.\n\nHowever, this game has some big problems: the interface is too slow, you have to confirm phase ends more than should be necessary and instead of keeping a running total of both players numbers it tediously adds them up once every two turns with a remarkably slow animation; and also you have character levels which add to your core numbers and make it practically impossible to find a fairish fight with fewer than 5000 players online (there are 50-100).

reviewText:
This is such a fun game that by the time I write this I did not even notice I had passed over 2 hours playing this.

Now, here is the bad right away, it CAN be difficult in the beginning, just because of the luck factor in the game; but on the other side of that sepectrum, this game is NOT, I repeat, NOT PAY TO WIN. You can play using the cards you get from battles or whatever you get in the randomized deck. That is the beauty about this game, the fact that it has more luck rather than who spends the most to win.


The graphics and artwork on cards is very detailed and really fits the fantasy-esque feel for the game.


But the bad thing about this game is it can feel dull and over repetitive. There is no real story and the campaign is simply you fighting random AI over and over again. Then after you beat campaign, you are left with multiplayer, which would not be bad, but there hardly seems to be players on and/or willing to play.


If you enjoy TCG and wanna kill some time, I  recommend you pick this title up and give it a shot for yourself.
But if you are looking for a RPG with story but some card elements, then you might wanna look somewhere else.

reviewText:
I like this game.  It is a bit grindy, but the game itself is fun enough to keep you playing.  I consider it to be one of the better free to play games.
You can choose between 3 classes and each class has its own subclasses.  There are elves, orcs, and humans to choose from and each have their own special ability card to use in battle.  You can have more than one character, but you have to pay real money for extra character slots.
To advance in the game, you need to complete bounty hunts or campaign missions.  Upon completion you get a good amount of gold and skill points.  These missions can take a while to finish, however.

At the moment my Elf Keeper is level 29.  The game is fun, but can be very challenging.  There are times when matches seem like a neverending stalemate.  It has come to the point where I completely surrender to Orcs because they are extremely powerful.  There are times when I try to fight them, but I get their health down half-way only for them to one-shot me.

I tried multiplayer once, but i couldn't stand waiting for my opponent's decision.  i will probably never do it again.

Overall, i DO recommend this game.  It is free, simple (takes a bit to grasp at first), fun, and it takes only a minute to download.  You can also play it for free on the phone, and fortunately your account carries over.  Although it is a bit slow on the phone, it works just as well.

reviewText:
This game has a lot of potential. I like the actual gameplay, it's just the meta-game that isn't very fun. Two things that come to mind are how you have to grind losses to level and have little control over gameplay since you unlock cards depending on how you play. By this I mean that you gain cards by playing them, so gameplay really just consists of stonewalling the enemy to prolong the game so that you might get lucky and draw a new card and then you essentially have no choice but to play it. That means gameplay follows the lines of the real-life card game War". You just draw cards and play them without making decisions.

Another issue is that combos are a pain to look up. I'd like to see if I have any combos in my hand without going through 3 dialogues for each and every card. Are we just supposed to remember them?

As it is
recommended: but with some changes outside of gameplay it could be a good game."

reviewText: It's complex; it's not complicated.  Most people don't understand the difference, but then most people can't differentiate between economics and budgeting, so I'm not really surprised by the simpletons who think that this game is simplistic.  Give it a go; it's free and it's a somewhat interesting take on the nearly worn-out electronic card game genre.

reviewText:
القرآن)، ولا تتم الصلاة (وعبادات أخرى) في الإسلام إلا بإتقان بعض العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير من أهم الأعمال الدينية والفكرية اليهودية في العصور الوسطى. وأثّر انتشار الإسلام، وتأسيسه دولاً، في ارتفاع مكانة اللغة العربية، وأصبحت لغة السياسة والعلم والأدب لقرون طويلة في الأراضي التي حكمها المسلمون، وأثرت العربية تأثيراً مباشراً أو غير مباشر على كثير من اللغات الأخرى في العالم الإسلامي، كالتركية والفارسية والأمازيغية والكردية والأردوية والماليزية والإندونيسية والألبانية وبعض اللغات الإفريقية الأخرى مثل الهاوسا والسواحيلية والتجرية والأمهرية و الصومالية، وبعض اللغات الأوروبية وخاصةً المتوسطية كالإسبانية والبرتغالية والمالطية والصقلية، كما أنها تُدرَّس بشكل رسمي أو غير رسمي في الدول الإسلامية والدول الإفريقية المحاذية للوطن العربي.
العربية لغة رسمية في كل دول الوطن العربي إضافة إلى كونها لغة رسمية في تشاد وإريتريا وإسرائيل. وهي إحدى اللغات الرسمية الست في منظمة الأمم المتحدة، ويُحتفل باليوم العالمي للغة العربية في يسمبركذكراعتماد العربية بين لغات العمل في الأمم المد
واللغة العربية من أغزر اللغات من حيث المادة اللغوية، فعلى سبيل المثال يحوي معجم لسان العرب لابن منظور من القرن الثالث عشر أكثر من ألف مادة، بينما في اللغة الإنجليزية فإن قاموس صموئيل جونسون وهو من أوائل من وضع قاموساً إنجليزياً من القرن الثامن عشر يحتوي على ألف كلم
تحتوي العربية على حرفاً مكتوباً. ويرى بعض اللغويين أنه يجب إضافة حرف الهمزة إلى حروف العربية، ليصبح عدد الحرو تُكتب العربية من اليمين إلى اليسار - ومثلها اللغة الفارسية والعبرية وعلى عكس الكثير من اللغات العالمية - ومن أعلى الصفحة إلى أسفلها.
العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير العربية هي أيضاً لغة شعائرية رئيسية لدى عدد من الكنائس المسيحية في الوطن العربي، كما كتبت بها الكثير

reviewText:
I have played this game around 6-10 hours out of steam, on browser.
*It is lagging a lot
*NPCs are not taking dmg on random rounds, so it makes harder to beat them, and the elite ones (or bosses) are impossible (even though  they are same lvl as me)
*You need a lot of gold to buy boosters (if you are not paying with VISA)
*You buy cards with credits which you obtain with gold purchases and you need 50$ for 500 credits with which i noticed I could buy only 2 cards


The game seems interesting, it need more options that a player can do with in game gold earned.

reviewText:
Concept:
A card game with a nice combo system where diff cards can combine into diff effects.  Some diff classes that present diff card types, which can be nice.

Graphics:
A card game.

Sound:
Decent, for a card game.

Entertainment:
Better than some, def not teh best.

Replay:
Average.

Rating:
Out of 60 USD  0-5
(Opinion on teh monetary worth of the game scaled 1 to 60$)

Conclusion:
Can be fun, not very.  Overall I'd say an average game worth checking out with no expectation for excellence.

reviewText:
Cons:
- Moving cards to deck after a match doesn't seem to work.
- Some cards are just better than others, like 14 mana,7 attack; 14 mana 9 attack, 11 mana 7 attack.
- Little variety, most cards just deal/prevent/heal damage.
- Luck based due to the random deck, you can often gain cards that cost too much. You need get mana for special cards or upgrades.
- Takes a long time to grind or you have to pay. Making another hero costs real money.

reviewText:
Don't know if its game mechanics or im just the most unlucky player ever.

So heres how my first 3 games went in campaign which is suppose to be easy mode considering its lvl 1.
So basically you had cards that either attack, defend, heal, dubuff and buff.  Now every time i successfully had a nice combo where i can do some decent damage, every single time the computer some how would get back to back damage prevention cards then back to back healing, and would keep my energy down almost every 2 turns (need energy to use cards.)  and when i finally got some healing cards it would what seems every time would get healing prevention cards.  Now i know this sounds like im being a poor sport or w/e but it happened none stop so dont know if game tries to annoy you to try get you to go buy more powerful items or something but it just made me not wanna play but hey its free game so give a try if you like getting punished, but then again could just be me being extra unlucky.

reviewText:
GREAT TCG GAME!!


-A Great TCG game on par with Magic the Gathering but contrast to mtg in it's game mechanics
-Absolutely Free. No gimmicks. F2W not p2w.
-The game has it's complexity in the combat phase than Magic the Gathering, although MTG is more diversify in the overall playing field.
-Intriguing gameplay, Balanced and in game complexity brings you into the world of True TCG like Magic the Gathering
-Fantastic soundtrack that brings you into such fantasy world.


I only write reviews that a game deserve it. And this game deserves this recognition. Look no to other tcg Free or mobile card games where only bloodsucking developers trying to leech every ounce of your money away. Those unbalanced gameplay where only one card rules it all and only suit to kiddy gameplay. I have played many other tcg games out there and none is as good as MTG and none is as close as MTG experience.


Now, Battlegrounds of Eldhelm is for you if you are a tcg lover and i am pretty sure MTG players will love this. The complexity level is pretty much intense than MTG in terms of combat phase but MTG is more diverse in the overall gameplay experience.

Battlegrounds of Eldhelm is a tcg in it's own right. It brings out the goodness in it but contrast to what magic can offer.

Calling all MTG avid players and MTG lovers to try this game. You will love it as much as i do.

:)

reviewText: Great RPG/strategy game. While in most TCG games luck is extremely important, Battlegrounds of Eldhelm" prefers skill and thinking.\n\nLearning combos
date: collecting cards for combos and improving your character (like any true RPG) is fun  - no matter if you're playing against AI or other players.\n\nTry it and try not to play it if you can. :)"

reviewText:
It's a fun game for a single player, but a dead one in terms of multiplayer play.

Had the availability to connect to one of two servers, and each one combined together was still less than 100 people online playing.

If you enjoy card games and solo-campaign play, then you'll probably enjoy this game.

If you enjoy playing against others, then you may find yourself frustrated as you wait for someone else. I also never truly completed a PVP match, as my opponent I'd be facing seemingly timed out or disconnected. I've no idea if it was poor luck in connections, or a case where the multiplayer code is horrendous.

The only thing that keeps me from really recommending it is if it's this dead now, even after a recent release for Mac's, then how much longer before the single player aspect disappears as well (since you're still online when playing solo).
